title: 115_s1021
content: The Act is titled the "United States Coast Guard Commemorative Coin Act of 2017". The United States Coast Guard was founded in 1790 as the Revenue Cutter Service under the Department of the Treasury. It was merged with the Lifesaving Service in 1915 and later became part of the Department of Homeland Security in 2003. Today, the Coast Guard conducts various missions to protect public safety, the environment, and economic interests in maritime regions. The United States Coast Guard, the oldest seagoing military service in the country, plays a vital role in homeland security, law enforcement, search and rescue, and marine environmental pollution response. With over 50,000 personnel, they conducted numerous operations in 2015, including 16,400 search and rescue cases saving 3,500 lives, 20,775 waterborne patrols, and security boardings in U.S. ports. The United States Coast Guard conducted operations in 2015, including search and rescue cases, waterborne patrols, and security boardings in U.S. ports. They removed $4.9 billion worth of illegal drugs, interdicted 6,000 undocumented migrants, and maintained navigation aids supporting $3.2 trillion in economic activity. The Coast Guard may establish a National Coast Guard Museum in New London, Connecticut. The National Coast Guard Museum Association aims to improve public understanding of the Coast Guard's history and missions. The United States Coast Guard, in collaboration with various stakeholders, is working on developing and funding the National Coast Guard Museum in New London, Connecticut. This museum aims to showcase the Coast Guard's history and legacy to the American public, as it is currently the only military service without a national museum. The National Coast Guard Museum in New London, Connecticut is being developed with the collaboration of stakeholders. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coin is specified in Section 4. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall reflect the traditions and history of the United States Coast Guard since 1790. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2020", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", "E Pluribus Unum", and "Semper Paratus". The design will honor both current and past Coastguardsmen in wartime. The design of the coins minted under this Act will reflect the traditions and history of the United States Coast Guard since 1790. The design will honor both current and past Coastguardsmen in wartime. The selected design must be consistent with the traditions and heritage of the Coast Guard, the National Coast Guard Museum, and the National Coast Guard Museum Association. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, the National Coast Guard Museum Association, and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint facilities will be used to strike coins, with a 1-year issuance period starting on January 1, 2020. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the National Coast Guard Museum Association for museum financing. The Association will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. The Act mandates surcharges for all coins minted, with specific amounts per coin denomination. Surcharges go to the National Coast Guard Museum Association for financing, with audits conducted. A limitation exists on the number of commemorative coin programs issued annually to avoid exceeding the set limit. The Secretary must ensure that minting coins under this Act does not cost the US Government and that all costs related to designing and issuing the coins are recovered before any funds are disbursed to recipients.
